title: 112_hr2867
content: The Act is titled the "United States Commission on International Religious Freedom Reform and Reauthorization Act of 2011." It establishes that each member of the Commission shall serve a 2-year term and may not serve more than 2 terms. Members who have completed 2 full terms will have their term expire 90 days after such date. The Act establishes term limits for members of the Commission, stating that they may not serve more than 2 terms and will be ineligible for reappointment if attendance at meetings falls below 75%. Additionally, members are not eligible for consecutive terms as Chair and must adhere to federal travel regulations. The Act establishes term limits for Commission members, requiring attendance at meetings above 75% to be eligible for reappointment. Members cannot serve more than 2 terms and cannot be Chair consecutively. The Act also mandates adherence to federal travel regulations and applies antidiscrimination laws to address violations in various employment areas. The Commission members have term limits and attendance requirements for reappointment. They are subject to federal travel regulations and antidiscrimination laws. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2012 through 2014. Standards of conduct and disclosure are amended to increase the threshold to $250,000. Section 208 of the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 is amended to increase the threshold to $250,000 and change "International Relations" to "Foreign Affairs". Section 209 is amended to change the termination date to September 30, 2014. A report on the effectiveness of programs to promote religious freedom must be submitted by the Comptroller General within one year of the Act's enactment. The curr_chunk discusses a review and assessment of various United States Government programs and entities related to promoting international religious freedom, including the Office on International Religious Freedom, the Ambassador at Large for International Religious Freedom, and the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom. It also includes a comparative analysis of the structure of the Commission in relation to other entities. The curr_chunk discusses the relationship between the Ambassador at Large for International Religious Freedom and the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom, and possible reforms to improve their effectiveness. The term "appropriate congressional committees" is defined in this section. The curr_chunk discusses the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
